{{Infobox comic book title <!--Wikipedia:WikiProject Comics--> |image = GodNose-cover.jpg |imagesize = |caption = The cover of ''God Nose'' (1964), by Jaxon. |schedule = |format = |1shot = Y |Superhero = |publisher = [[Jaxon|Jack Jackson]] |date = [[1964 in comics|1964]] |issues = |main_char_team = [[God]], [[Jesus Christ]] |writers = [[Jaxon]] |artists = [[Jaxon]] |pencillers = |inkers = |letterers = |colorists = |editors = |creative_team_month = |creative_team_year = |creators = |TPB = |ISBN = |TPB# = |ISBN# = |subcat = |altcat = |sort = God Nose }} '''''God Nose''''' is a 42-page American [[comic book]] produced in 1964 by [[Jaxon|Jack "Jaxon" Jackson]] and is considered one of the first [[underground comix]].<ref>[http://www.austinchronicle.com/screens/2010-03-12/977251/ SXSW Film - Letting the Freak Brothers Flag Fly: Gilbert Shelton on his iconic comic's long, strange trip to the screen - Screens - The Austin Chronicle<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.austinchronicle.com/arts/2011-03-18/esthers-follies/ Esther's Follies: After 30 years, Awn is off - Arts - The Austin Chronicle<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.austinchronicle.com/arts/2006-12-22/431062/ The Comics (Artist) Panel: Five Austinites on the state of the sequential art, from comics to comix to manga and beyond - Arts - The Austin Chronicle<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> ''God Nose'' centers on philosophical discussions between God and the "fools he rules."<ref>Booke, Keith M. 2010, ''Encyclopedia of Comic Books and Graphic Novels'', ABC-CLIO, LLC, Santa Barbara, CA</ref>
== Overview == ''God Nose'' portrays God as an old man with a white beard and a crown, sitting on a golden throne in Heaven. He and [[Jesus Christ|Jesus]] discuss modern life, including such controversial topics as [[birth control]] and racism. At one point, Jesus returns to Earth to be a [[folk singer]]. (He also tries [[surfing]].) God also visits Earth, at one point materializing into the bedroom of a couple as they are about to make love.
== Publication history == Jaxon's ''God Nose'' strip first appeared in the Florida college fanzine ''Charlatan'', where it was published from 1963 to at least 1966.
In 1964, Jaxon collected a number of the previous strips, and printed 1,000 copies on a [[Xerox]] machine at the Texas State Capital print shop after hours.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=grtJlJK7p5A&feature=plcp TEDxCMU - Zach Weiner - The Fall and Rise of the American Comic Strip - YouTube<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://comics.ha.com/c/item.zx?saleNo=826&lotNo=42140 God Nose #1 (Jack Jackson, 1964) Condition: VF Silver Age (1956-1969)Alternative/Underground<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://lambiek.net/artists/j/jackson.htm "Comic creator: Jack Jackson (Jaxon),"] Lambiek ''Comiclopedia''. Accessed Sept. 20, 2010.</ref> The first printing of ''God Nose'' is 8-1/2" x 11" in size and 42 pages long.<ref name=ComixJoint>Fox, M. Steven. [http://comixjoint.com/godnose-2nd.html "God Nose,"] ComixJoint. Accessed Dec. 5, 2016.</ref>
[[Rip Off Press]], an underground publisher co-founded by Jaxon, did a second printing in 1969, with a revised cover lacking a cover price and with a pink border with red central color. The third printing, also by Rip Off Press, has a blue border with green central color and a 50c price below the basketball hoop. Rip Off Press did a fourth and final printing in 1971; it has a red border with yellow central color and a 50c cover price. The second-fourth printings are standard comic book size, 44 pages long.<ref name=ComixJoint />
The entirety of ''God Nose'' was also reprinted as ''Underground Classics'' (Rip Off Press, 1985 series) #6 (1988).

[[Yale University]] | employer = [[New York University]] | occupation = Historian | title = | salary = | networth = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse = | children = | parents = | relatives = }} '''Greg Grandin''' (born 1962) is a professor of history at [[New York University]].{{cite web|url=http://history.fas.nyu.edu/object/greggrandin |title=NYU > History > Greg Grandin |publisher=History.fas.nyu.edu |accessdate=October 21, 2011}} He is author of a number of books, including ''[[Fordlândia#Legacy and depictions|Fordlândia]]: The Rise and Fall of Henry Ford's Forgotten Jungle City'', which was a finalist for the [[Pulitzer Prize for History]], as well as for the [[National Book Award]]{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalbook.org/nba2009_nf_grandin.html |title=The National Book Foundation |publisher=Nationalbook.org |accessdate=October 21, 2011}} and a [[National Book Critics Circle Award]].{{cite web|url=http://bookcritics.org/blog/archive/30_books_in_30_days_fordlandia_by_greg_grandin/) |title=National Book Critics Circle: 30 Books in 30 Days: Fordlandia, by Greg Grandin – Critical Mass Blog |publisher=Bookcritics.org |date=March 9, 2010 |accessdate=October 21, 2011}} A more recent book, entitled, ''Who Is [[Rigoberta Menchú]]?'', focuses on the treatment of the Guatemalan [[Nobel Peace Prize]] winner. His latest book, ''The Empire of Necessity: Slavery, Freedom, and Deception in the New World,'' is a study of the factual basis for the novella ''[[Benito Cereno]]'' by [[Herman Melville]]. ''Fordlandia'' was named a best book of the year by ''The [[New York Times]]'',{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/gift-guide/holiday-2009/100-notable-books-of-2009-gift-guide/list.html | work=The New York Times}} ''[[The New Yorker]]'';{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/arts/reviews/brieflynoted/2009/12/14/091214crbn_brieflynoted |title=Briefly Noted: "A Year's Reading" |work=The New Yorker |date=August 1, 2011 |accessdate=October 21, 2011}} [[NPR]];{{cite web|last=Heller |first=Zoe |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=121708080 |title=Maureen Corrigan's Best Books Of 2009 |publisher=NPR |date=December 23, 2009 |accessdate=October 21, 2011}} ''The [[Boston Globe]]'';{{cite news| url=http://www.boston.com/ae/books/articles/2009/12/06/simply_the_best_nonfiction/?page=2 | work=The Boston Globe | first=Michael | last=Kenney | title=Simply the best nonfiction | date=December 6, 2009}} ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'';{{cite web|url=http://scienceblogs.com/confessions/2010/01/best_science_books_2009_san_fr.php |title=Best Science Books 2009: San Francisco Chronicle : Confessions of a Science Librarian |publisher=Scienceblogs.com |date=January 6, 2010 |accessdate=October 21, 2011}} and the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]''.{{cite news|url=http://featuresblogs.chicagotribune.com/printers-row/our-favorite-nonfiction-of-2009.html |work=Chicago Tribune |title=Our favorite nonfiction of 2009 |date=April 12, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091213012153/http://featuresblogs.chicagotribune.com/printers-row/our-favorite-nonfiction-of-2009.html |archivedate=December 13, 2009 }} ==Biography== Grandin graduated from [[Brooklyn College]] with a B.A. (1992) and from [[Yale University]] with a Ph.D. (1999).http://history.fas.nyu.edu/object/history.faculty.grandin.interests He won the [[Latin American Studies Association]]'s Bryce Wood Award for the best book published in any discipline on [[Latin America]] for ''Blood of Guatemala: A History of Race and Nation''. [[Eric Hobsbawm]] called ''The Last Colonial Massacre'' a "remarkable and extremely well-written work" that
is about more than the dark history of Guatemala and the Cold War in Latin America. It is about how common people discover politics. It is about the roots of democracy and those of genocide. It is about the hopes and defeats of the twentieth-century left. I could not put this book down.{{cite web|url=http://www.press.uchicago.edu/Misc/Chicago/305724in.html |title=Interview with Greg Grandin author of The Last Colonial Massacre: Latin America in the Cold War |publisher=Press.uchicago.edu |date=May 29, 1978 |accessdate=October 21, 2011}}
Grandin has published widely on [[US foreign policy]], the [[Cold War]], and Latin American politics in ''[[The Nation]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.thenation.com/authors/greg-grandin/ |title=Greg Grandin |publisher=The Nation |accessdate=August 25, 2015}} ''The New York Times'',{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/14/books/review/Grandin-t.html | work=The New York Times | first=Greg | last=Grandin | title=Empire of Savagery in the Amazon | date=February 14, 2010}} ''[[Harper's Magazine|Harpers]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.harpers.org/archive/2004/12/0080329 |title=The right quagmire: Searching history for an imperial alibi—By Greg Grandin (Harper's Magazine) |publisher=Harpers.org |accessdate=October 21, 2011}} the ''[[London Review of Books]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.lrb.co.uk/v29/n23/greg-grandin/sucking-up-to-p |title=Greg Grandin reviews 'Nixon and Kissinger' by Robert Dallek and 'Henry Kissinger and the American Century' by Jeremi Suri |date=29 November 2007 |publisher=LRB |accessdate=October 21, 2011}} and [[TomDispatch.com]].http://www.google.com/search?q=%22greg+grandin%22&search=GO&domains=www.tomdispatch.com&sitesearch=www.tomdispatch.com He has appeared on the ''[[Charlie Rose (talk show)|Charlie Rose Show]]'' and has interviewed [[Naomi Klein]]{{cite web|url=http://www.naomiklein.org/shock-doctrine/reviews/nacla |title=Body Shock: A 40th Anniversary Conversation with |publisher=Naomi Klein |accessdate=October 21, 2011}} and [[Hugo Chávez]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thenation.com/doc/20091012/grandin |title=October 12, 2009 |publisher=The Nation |accessdate=October 21, 2011}} In the summer of 2009, he reported from [[Honduras]] on [[2009 Honduran constitutional crisis|that country's coup]], appearing a number of times on ''[[Democracy Now!]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.democracynow.org/2009/7/24/defying_coup_regime_zelaya_attempts_return |title=Defying Coup Regime, Zelaya Attempts Return to Honduras |publisher=Democracynow.org |accessdate=October 21, 2011}} and Grit TV{{cite web|url=http://www.freespeech.org/video/grittv-greg-grandin-echoes-80s-honduras |title=GRITtv: Greg Grandin: Echoes of the 80s In Honduras |publisher=[[Free Speech TV]] |accessdate=October 21, 2011}} and writing a series of reports in ''The Nation'' and elsewhere on the consequences of the [[2009 Honduran coup d'état|overthrow]] of Honduran president [[Manuel Zelaya]]. Grandin worked as a consultant with the [[Historical Clarification Commission]] (Spanish: Comisión para el Esclarecimiento Histórico, or CEH), the Guatemalan truth commission, and has written a number of articles on its methodology, including its [[genocide]] rulinghttp://www.cambridge.org/us/catalogue/catalogue.asp?isbn=0521527503) (http://muse.jhu.edu/login?uri=/journals/nepantla/v001/1.2grandin.html and its use of historical analysis.{{cite web|url=http://www.historycooperative.org/journals/ahr/110.1/grandin.html |author=Greg Grandin|title= The Instruction of Great Catastrophe: Truth Commissions, National History, and State Formation in Argentina, Chile, and Guatemala |work= [[The American Historical Review]], 110.1 |publisher=[[The History Cooperative]] |accessdate=October 21, 2011|date=February 2005| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060903092616/http://www.historycooperative.org/journals/ahr/110.1/grandin.html | archivedate=September 3, 2006 |deadurl=yes}} Grandin was a finalist for the [[Pulitzer Prize]] in 2010.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/13/business/media/2010-Arts-Pulitzers.html | work=The New York Times | title=2010 Pulitzer Prizes for Letters, Drama and Music | date=April 12, 2010}} Grandin was elected to the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] in April 2010.http://www.amacad.org/news/a2z10.pdf ==Selected works== {{external media | width = 210px | align = right | audio1 = [https://www.npr.org/2014/01/27/265230687/on-this-spanish-slave-ship-nothing-was-as-it-seemed On This Spanish Slave Ship, Nothing Was As It Seemed], Review of ''The Empire of Necessity'', 5:57, [[Maureen Corrigan]], [[Fresh Air]], [[NPR]], January 27, 2014{{cite web | title =On This Spanish Slave Ship, Nothing Was As It Seemed | work = Review of ''The Empire of Necessity'' | publisher =[[Fresh Air]] on [[NPR]] | date = January 27, 2014 | url =https://www.npr.org/2014/01/27/265230687/on-this-spanish-slave-ship-nothing-was-as-it-seemed | accessdate =March 6, 2018 }} }} ===Author=== *{{cite book| title=The blood of Guatemala: a history of race and nation|publisher=Duke University Press| year= 2000| isbn=978-0-8223-2495-9 }} *{{cite book| title=The last colonial massacre: Latin America in the Cold War | publisher=University of Chicago Press| year= 2004 | isbn=978-0-226-30571-4}} *{{cite book| title=Empire's Workshop: Latin America, the United States, and the Rise of the New Imperialism| publisher=Macmillan| year= 2007| isbn= 978-0-8050-8323-1 }} *{{cite book| title=Fordlandia: The Rise and Fall of Henry Ford's Forgotten Jungle City | publisher=Macmillan| year= 2010| isbn= 978-0-312-42962-1 }} *''Who Is Rigoberta Menchu?'', Verso, 2011, {{ISBN|978-1-84467-458-9}} * ''The Empire of Necessity: Slavery, Freedom, and Deception in the New World'', Metropolitan Books, 2014, {{ISBN|9780805094534}} * ''Kissinger's Shadow: The Long Reach of America's Most Controversial Statesman'', Metropolitan Books, 2015, {{ISBN|9781627794497}} * "The Strange Career of American Exceptionalism", ''[[The Nation]]'', January 2/9, 2017, pp. 22–27. ===Editor=== *{{cite book| title=Truth Commissions: State Terror, History, and Memory| editors= Greg Grandin, Thomas Miller Klubock | publisher=Duke University Press| year= 2007| isbn= 978-0-8223-6674-4 }} *{{cite book| title=A Century of Revolution |editors= Greg Grandin, Gilbert M. Stewart Burns]] | director = [[Rob Oliver]] | blackboard = "Cafeteria trays are not [[toboggans]]". | couch_gag = The [[Simpson family]], as gingerbread people, jumps on a plate for [[Santa Claus]], and [[Homer Simpson|Homer]] eats his own arm. | guest_star = | commentary = | season = 23 }}
"'''Holidays of Future Passed'''" is the ninth episode of the [[The Simpsons (season 23)|twenty-third season]] of the American animated sitcom ''[[The Simpsons]]''. It originally aired on the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox network]] in the United States on December 11, 2011. Most of the episode is set thirty years into the future, when [[Bart Simpson|Bart]] and [[Lisa Simpson|Lisa]] take their children with them to [[Homer Simpson|Homer]] and [[Marge Simpson|Marge]]'s house over Christmas, while a pregnant [[Maggie Simpson|Maggie]] goes into labor. Bart has divorced his wife Jenda and is struggling to become a better father for his two boys, while Lisa has trouble connecting with her rebellious teenage daughter Zia. ''The Simpsons'' creator [[Matt Groening]] made a minor uncredited cameo appearance as a [[sports commentator]] shouting "goal!" during a [[Association football|soccer]] game.
Originally written as a potential [[series finale]], the episode has received highly positive reception from television critics who often cited it as the best episode of the season. It has been particularly praised for its humor and for its emotional scenes, such as one where Bart and Lisa sit in their old [[treehouse]] and talk about how difficult parenting is. During the original broadcast, "Holidays of Future Passed" was watched by about 6.43 million people. Since then, it has garnered attention in the media for a segment taking place thirty years in the future in which it is implied that the city of [[Dearborn, Michigan]] is "still under [[sharia law]]". Commentators have had mixed opinions on what the segment is mocking, whether it is the increasing Islamic influence in the US, specifically in Dearborn, or rather those who are thinking that Dearborn is under sharia law in December 2011, the time that the episode aired.
==Plot== After stuffing themselves with turkey on [[Thanksgiving]], it is time to take the annual [[Christmas card]] family photo, and when [[Bart Simpson|Bart]] and [[Lisa Simpson|Lisa]] complain about it, [[Marge Simpson|Marge]] notes that they will grow to appreciate the photos when they become older and have children of their own. Lisa questions why Marge would assume they will even have children in the first place while Bart confidently claims that he won't, desiring for the Simpson family's legacy of dysfunction to cease. The episode jumps thirty years into the future via a series of Simpsons Christmas cards. The photos finally settle on a future where Bart is a deadbeat, divorced father with two sons whom he does not see often; Lisa is a successful businesswoman who is married to [[Milhouse Van Houten|Milhouse]] and has a rebellious daughter named Zia; and [[Maggie Simpson|Maggie]] is the lead singer of a famous band and in the late stages of pregnancy. In his apartment at the former [[Springfield Elementary]], Bart is visited by his sons, who inform him that their mother [[Future-Drama|Jenda]] teleported them to his place because she wants him to act like a proper father by having him spend time with them. However, he plans on dropping them off at his parents' house instead. Meanwhile, Lisa fears that Zia is spending too much of her time going into the "Ultranet", a digital world that people enter with their consciousness by plugging themselves into a laptop. Milhouse suggests to Lisa that she spend time with Zia in order for them to have a better connection, so Lisa decides to take Zia to her parents' house, too. Meanwhile, Maggie flies home from London to Springfield to also celebrate Christmas with her parents.
When Bart and Lisa arrive at their parents' home, they stay there with their children. Unfortunately for Lisa, she only gets unhelpful advice from Marge on how to be a better mother and Zia continues to go into the Ultranet. Meanwhile, Bart is heartbroken to find out that Jenda has remarried while he has not found anyone new. Feeling depressed, he tells [[Homer Simpson|Homer]] to take his grandsons out. The boys become angry with their father for not spending time with them, but the two have a great time with their grandfather. Bart and Lisa then encounter each other in their old treehouse, where they become slightly [[Alcohol intoxication|drunk]] and talk about how difficult parenting is. After exchanging inspirational advice, they realize that they need to try harder to connect with their children. Meanwhile, upon arriving in Springfield, Maggie starts experiencing contractions and [[List of recurring The Simpsons characters#Kearney Zzyzwicz|Kearney]], now a taxi driver, drives her to the hospital.
Homer takes Bart's sons to a [[cryonics]] facility where [[Grampa Simpson|Grampa]] has been frozen alive to prevent a disease from killing him. Although a cure has now been discovered, he is kept frozen by Homer because it is cheaper than paying for a nursing home and because Grampa has constantly been rude to him. Homer says to the boys that they should give their father another chance, since he knows Bart loves them. At that point, Bart arrives and apologizes to his sons, admitting how much he treasures them. Touched, the two boys forgive him for not having included them in his life much, while an inspired Homer decides to unfreeze Grampa and forgive him as well. Meanwhile, Lisa goes into the Ultranet to find Zia and discovers a door leading into Zia's private world. Entering it, Lisa is overjoyed to find that Zia has hung a poster of her next to a series of posters depicting historical women who have made a difference in the world. When Zia arrives, Lisa thanks her for looking up to her and the two reconcile at last, and secretly hides her life as a party poser. With the conflicts resolved, Bart and Lisa gather their children in preparation for a new Christmas family photo. Marge arrives with Maggie, who has given birth to a baby girl. The Simpsons gather into a group just as the family pets (who have evolved greatly over the past thirty years) take the new photo.
==Production== [[File:Matt Groening by Gage Skidmore 2.jpg|thumb|upright|The episode features a minor uncredited cameo from ''The Simpsons'' creator [[Matt Groening]].]] The episode, titled "Holidays of Future Passed", was written by [[J. Stewart Burns]] and directed by Rob Oliver.<ref name=Ledesma1>{{cite web|last=Ledesma|first=Chris (music editor for ''The Simpsons'')|title='The Ten-Per-Cent Solution' and 'Holidays of Future Passed'|url=http://simpsonsmusic500.wordpress.com/2011/11/23/the-ten-per-cent-solution-and-holidays-of-future-passed/|publisher=Simpsons Music 500|accessdate=2011-12-09|date=2011-11-23}}</ref><ref>{{Cite episode |title=Holidays of Future Passed |episodelink= |series=The Simpsons |serieslink=The Simpsons |credits= |network=Fox |station= |airdate=2011-12-11 |season=23|seriesno= |number=9 |minutes=04:04–04:13 |quote= |language=}}</ref> It was first announced to the press at the [[San Diego Comic-Con International|Comic-Con]] convention in [[San Diego, California]] on July 23, 2011, during a panel with the producers of ''The Simpsons''.<ref name=Snierson07-23>{{cite news|last=Snierson|first=Dan|title=10 things we learned about 'The Simpsons' at Comic-Con|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2011/07/23/simpsons-comic-con-season-23/|accessdate=2011-12-09|newspaper=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=2011-07-23}}</ref> "Holidays of Future Passed" is the eleventh episode of the series with a Christmas theme, and the fourth episode set in the future (the others being "[[Lisa's Wedding]]" from 1995, "[[Bart to the Future]]" from 2000, and "[[Future-Drama]]" from 2005).<ref name=Childs>{{cite news|last=Childs|first=Hayden|title='Holidays Of Future Passed'|url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/holidays-of-future-passed,66387/|accessdate=2011-12-12|newspaper=[[The A.V. Club]]|date=2011-12-12}}</ref> Originally there was a joke in the episode about a [[Nuclear meltdown|meltdown]] occurring at the [[Springfield Nuclear Power Plant]] in the future; however, it was cut following the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]] that resulted in [[2011 Japanese nuclear accidents|several nuclear accidents]] in Japan.<ref name=Fowler>{{cite web|last=Fowler|first=Matt|title=The Simpsons to Parody Dexter/Inception|url=http://tv.ign.com/articles/118/1184547p1.html|publisher=[[IGN]]|accessdate=2011-12-20|date=2011-07-27}}</ref>
''The Simpsons'' creator [[Matt Groening]] made a minor cameo in the episode, though his appearance is not mentioned in the [[closing credits]].<ref name=Ledesma/> In the episode, a robot examines the health of Maggie's fetus. Maggie's band is present, and one of the band members presses a button on the robot's "face", which is a screen showing its facial expressions, and a soccer game comes on instead.<ref>{{Cite episode |title=Holidays of Future Passed |episodelink= |series=The Simpsons |serieslink=The Simpsons |credits= |network=Fox |station= |airdate=2011-12-11 |season=23|seriesno= |number=9 |minutes=04:57–05:20 |quote= |language=}}</ref> A sports commentator, voiced by Groening, gives a long "goal!" shout that is heard over the game. According to ''The Simpsons'' music editor Chris Ledesma, as the episode was being recorded, "there were only sounds of crowd cheering during that shot and Matt said we needed to spice it up somehow."<ref name=Ledesma/> After going through some different ideas, the staff settled on a commentator shouting "goal!". The staff members wanted Groening to provide the voice and he finished the recording in two takes.<ref name=Ledesma>{{cite web|last=Ledesma|first=Chris |title=Wrapping Up 2011|url=http://simpsonsmusic500.wordpress.com/2011/12/13/wrapping-up-2011/|publisher=Simpsons Music 500|accessdate=2011-12-14|date=2011-12-13}}</ref>
In a 2013 interview with former show writer [[Conan O'Brien]], Jean stated that this episode was intended to serve as a [[series finale]] in the case that cast negotiations earlier in the year forced the show to end.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Chan|first1=Anna|title='Simpsons' series finale? You've seen it -- sort of|url=http://www.today.com/popculture/simpsons-series-finale-youve-seen-it-sort-1C9380740|work=[[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today]]|publisher=[[NBC]]|date=2012-02-15}}</ref>
==Release== "Holidays of Future Passed" originally aired on the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox network]] in the United States on December 11, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|last=Toby|first=Mekeisha Madden|title=It's the most wonderful (TV) time of the year|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/12/01/showbiz/tv/holiday-tv-shows/|publisher=[[CNN]]|accessdate=2011-12-09|date=2011-12-01}}</ref><ref name=Roush>{{cite news|last=Roush|first=Matt|title=The Guide to Weekend TV: Sundance's Appropriate Adult, A Bag of Bones, and More!|url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/Guide-Weekend-TV-1040677.aspx|accessdate=2011-12-10|newspaper=[[TV Guide]]|date=2011-12-09}}</ref> The episode was watched by approximately 6.43 million people during this broadcast, and in the [[Nielsen ratings#Demographics|demographic for adults aged 18–49]], it received a 3.0 [[Nielsen ratings#Ratings/share and total viewers|Nielsen rating]] and a seven percent [[Nielsen ratings#Ratings/share and total viewers|share]].<ref name=ratings2>{{cite web|last=Seidman|first=Robert|title=Sunday Final Ratings: No Adjustments for 'Once Upon A Time' + Giants/Cowboys & Unscrambled CBS|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2011/12/13/sunday-final-ratings-no-adjustments-for-once-upon-a-time-giantscowboys-unscrambled-cbs/113477/|publisher=[[TV by the Numbers]]|accessdate=2011-12-13|date=2011-12-13}}</ref> This was a decrease from the previous episode, "[[The Ten-Per-Cent Solution]]", which received a 4.0 rating. However, that episode was preceded by a popular [[National Football League]] game that helped increase its rating.<ref name=ratings1>{{cite web|last=Seidman|first=Robert|title=TV Ratings Sunday: 'Once Upon a Time' Continues To Fall; Fox Animations Down + Scrambled CBS|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2011/12/12/tv-ratings-sunday-once-upon-a-time-continues-to-fall-fox-animations-down-scrambled-cbs/113388/|publisher=[[TV by the Numbers]]|accessdate=2011-12-12|date=2011-12-12}}</ref><ref name=deadline>{{cite web|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|title=Ratings Rat Race: ‘Once Upon A Time’ Hits New Low, ‘Amazing Race’ Finale Down|url=http://www.deadline.com/2011/12/ratings-rat-race-once-upon-a-time-hits-new-low-amazing-race-finale-down/|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|accessdate=2011-12-12|date=2011-12-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Eames|first=Tom|title='Once Upon a Time', 'The Simpsons' fall in Sunday ratings|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/ustv/s181/once-upon-a-time/news/a355665/once-upon-a-time-the-simpsons-fall-in-sunday-ratings.html|publisher=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=2011-12-12|date=2011-12-12}}</ref> "Holidays of Future Passed" became the most-watched broadcast in Fox's [[Animation Domination]] lineup for the night in terms of total viewers, finishing higher than new episodes of the three series ''[[Family Guy]]'' (6.10 million), ''[[The Cleveland Show]]'' (5.07 million), and ''[[American Dad!]]'' (5.00 million). It also became the second highest-rated broadcast among adults aged 18–49, being exceeded only by the ''Family Guy'' episode which received a 3.1 rating.<ref name=ratings2/> For the week of {{nowrap|December 5–11, 2011,}} the episode placed twentieth in the ratings among all prime-time network broadcasts in the 18–49 demographic.<ref>{{cite web|last=Seidman|first=Robert|title=TV Ratings Broadcast Top 25: 'Sunday Night Football,' 'Modern Family,' 'Two and a Half Men' Top Week 12|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2011/12/13/tv-ratings-broadcast-top-25-sunday-night-football-modern-family-two-and-a-half-men-top-week-12/113498/|publisher=[[TV by the Numbers]]|accessdate=2011-12-13|date=2011-12-13}}</ref>
===Critical reviews=== Since airing, "Holidays of Future Passed" has received highly positive reviews from television critics, particularly for its humor and emotional scenes. In his list of "The 50 Best TV Episodes of 2011", [[BuddyTV]]'s John Kubicek placed the episode at number forty-nine, writing that the "various glimpses of how all the other characters have changed during the time jump was a cavalcade of comedy moments."<ref name=Kubicek>{{cite web|last=Kubicek|first=John|title=The 50 Best TV Episodes of 2011|url=http://www.buddytv.com/slideshows/friday-night-lights/the-50-best-tv-episodes-of-2011-5525.aspx|publisher=[[BuddyTV]]|accessdate=2011-12-20|date=2011-12-19}}</ref> Rex Huffman of ''[[GateHouse Media|The Times-Reporter]]'' cited it as "an amusing episode",<ref name=Huffman>{{cite news|last=Huffman |first=Rex |title='Christmas in Connecticut,' 'Battle of the Bulbs' on tap tonight |url=http://www.timesreporter.com/newsnow/x230572099/Christmas-in-Connecticut-Battle-of-the-Bulbs-on-tap-tonight |accessdate=2011-12-16 |newspaper=[[GateHouse Media|The Times-Reporter]] |date=2011-12-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120108022038/http://www.timesreporter.com/newsnow/x230572099/Christmas-in-Connecticut-Battle-of-the-Bulbs-on-tap-tonight |archivedate=2012-01-08 |df= }}</ref> and [[Ology (website)|Ology]]'s Josh Harrison described it as "legitimately funny".<ref name=Harrison/> Harrison noted that "seeing so many futuristic versions of familiar characters put an interesting spin on the holiday season."<ref name=Harrison/> He also commented: "The whole episode hinges on a surprisingly heartfelt scene that sees Bart and Lisa—both a bit sloshed—meeting up in the treehouse to discuss the challenges of parenting."<ref name=Harrison>{{cite web|last=Harrison |first=Josh |title='The Simpsons' Recap: 'Holidays Of Future Passed' |url=http://www.ology.com/tv/simpsons-recap-holidays-future-passed/12112011 |publisher=[[Ology (website)|Ology]] |accessdate=2011-12-12 |date=2011-12-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120108010157/http://www.ology.com/tv/simpsons-recap-holidays-future-passed/12112011 |archivedate=2012-01-08 |df= }}</ref> Similarly, Hayden Childs of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' wrote that "Holidays of Future Passed" found "a sweet spot that combined a barrage of non-stop jokes with a tenderness often lacking in latter-day ''Simpsons'' episodes. There is even a conversation between the adult Bart and Lisa that rings surprisingly true for adult siblings wrestling with their shared familial past."<ref name="Childs"/>
Writing for [[HitFix]], [[Alan Sepinwall]] cited "Holidays of Future Passed" as the best future-set episode of ''The Simpsons'' since the first one, "Lisa's Wedding". He noted that it was "the emotional side of things" that made the episode successful, such as the dissatisfaction Bart and Lisa feel because of their disconnection with the children, and also Homer's transformation into a "very wise, sweet guy after somehow surviving into old age."<ref name=Sepinwall/> Sepinwall particularly praised the scene at the cryonics facility where Homer encourages the children to give Bart another chance as "really sweet", and he described the idea of a frozen Grampa as "a clever variation on the very familiar joke of how Homer and the family neglect [Grampa] because he's such a pain in the ass."<ref name=Sepinwall/> Sepinwall also commended the episode for its jokes about the future, highlighting the scenes revolving around air travel as well as the scenes showing [[Krusty the Clown|Krusty]] as "the [[Andy Rooney]] of 2041" and [[Ralph Wiggum]] as "an endless series of stupid clones who keep killing one another."<ref name=Sepinwall>{{cite web|last=Sepinwall|first=Alan|title=Review: 'The Simpsons' - 'Holidays of Future Passed': The darkest timeline?|url=http://www.hitfix.com/blogs/whats-alan-watching/posts/the-simpsons-holidays-of-future-passed-the-darkest-timeline|publisher=[[HitFix]]|accessdate=2011-12-16|date=2011-12-12}}</ref> In February 2012, "Holidays of Future Passed" was listed by Matt Zoller Seitz of ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine as one of "Nine Latter-Day ''Simpsons'' Episodes That Match Up to the Early Classics". He noted that the "reconciliations between Bart and Lisa and their kids are moving."<ref name=vulture>{{cite news|url=http://www.vulture.com/2012/02/nine-simpsons-episodes-as-good-as-early-classics.html|title=Nine Latter-Day Simpsons Episodes That Match Up to the Early Classics|date=2012-02-10|accessdate=2012-02-10|last=Seitz|first=Matt Zoller|newspaper=[[New York (magazine)|New York]]}}</ref>
At the [[64th Primetime Emmy Awards]] in 2012, "Holidays of Future Passed" was nominated for the [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Animated Program (for Programming Less Than One Hour)]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emmys.com/shows/simpsons|title=The Simpsons|work=Emmys.com|publisher=Academy of Television Arts and Sciences|accessdate=2011-07-14}}</ref>
===Response to Islamic references=== [[File:Arab American National Museum.jpg|thumb|A scene portraying [[Dearborn, Michigan]] as under [[sharia law]] received a mixed reception in the city]] A segment of "Holidays of Future Passed" was inspired by a controversy over the growing Islamic influence in the city of [[Dearborn, Michigan]], which has "a significant Muslim community".<ref name=Gallagher/> The biggest [[mosque]] in the United States is also located there.<ref name=Gallagher>{{cite news|last=Gallagher |first=Bill |title='Simpsons' Episode References Dearborn |url=http://www.myfoxdetroit.com/dpp/news/local/simpsons-episode-references-dearborn-20111212-ms |accessdate=2011-12-17 |newspaper=''[[WJBK]]'' |date=2011-12-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120410194355/http://www.myfoxdetroit.com/dpp/news/local/simpsons-episode-references-dearborn-20111212-ms |archivedate=2012-04-10 |df= }}</ref> During the segment in question, set in Milhouse and Lisa's future home, Milhouse tells Lisa that he has started to feel the symptoms of his seasonal allergies now that Christmas has arrived. He is apparently allergic to Christmas-related things such as [[holly]], [[mistletoe]], and the red part of [[candy cane]]. Lisa advises Milhouse to go and stay in [[Michigan]] over the holidays, where Christmas is not celebrated because it is "still under [[sharia law]]."<ref name="dearbornscene"/> Milhouse agrees to do this, but complains that they always make him wear a veil there, pointing to a photo on the wall in which he is standing outside of the [[University of Michigan–Dearborn]] dressed in a [[burqa]].<ref name="dearbornscene">{{Cite episode |title=Holidays of Future Passed |episodelink= |series=The Simpsons |serieslink=The Simpsons |credits= |network=Fox |station= |airdate=2011-12-11 |season=23|seriesno= |number=9 |minutes=03:46–04:48 |quote= |language=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=‘Simpsons’ episode spoofs fear of Sharia law|url=http://downriversundaytimes.com/2011/12/17/%E2%80%98simpsons%E2%80%99-episode-spoofs-fear-of-sharia-law/|accessdate=11-12-18|newspaper=Dearborn Times-Herald|date=11-12-17|author=Heraty, Daniel}}</ref><ref name=Shellnutt>{{cite news|last=Shellnutt|first=Kate|title=The Simpsons holiday episode mocks shariah law in the U.S.|url=http://blog.chron.com/believeitornot/2011/12/the-simpsons-holiday-episode-mocks-shariah-law-in-the-u-s/|accessdate=2011-12-17|newspaper=[[Houston Chronicle]]|date=2011-12-12}}</ref>
In a news report about this segment that aired on WJBK, Gallagher noted that it "poked fun at the untrue and unfounded notion that somehow Muslim sharia law prevails in Dearborn."<ref name=Gallagher/> Dawud Walid, head of the Michigan branch of the [[Council on American-Islamic Relations]], commented in the report that ''The Simpsons'' "is a very prolific show. Now [it] is addressing this anti-sharia fear mongering issue, and perhaps it may gain some currency and ... more people will make fun of it."<ref name=Gallagher/> The segment was met with mixed reception from students at University of Michigan–Dearborn. A number of them were interviewed by Gallagher in his report. One student said: "It's pretty cool showing how ridiculous the hate is. I think it's pretty funny," while another noted: "I don't think it's a good thing [to mock anti-Islamic bigotry] because we can change it by talking, not making fun."<ref name=Gallagher/>

| denomination = [[Church of England]] | churchmanship = [[Liberal Anglo-Catholicism|Liberal Catholic]] | diocese = [[Diocese of London]] | parish = [[Hackney (parish)|Hackney]] | coordinates = {{coord|51|32|39.6|N|0|4|23.3|W|type:landmark_region:GB-HCK|display=inline,title}} | division = | subdivision = | founded date = | founder = | architect = [[Ewan Christian]] | style = | years built = 1879 | dedicated date = | closed date = | demolished date = | bishop = | priest = | archdeacon = | dean = | provost = | rector = | canon = | prebendary = | curate = | chaplain = | vicar = ''[[interregnum]]'' | deacon = | abbot = | minister = | seniorpastor = | pastor = | location = [[London Borough of Hackney]] | country = [[United Kingdom]]
| website = [http://www.trinitysaintsunited.com/ Holy Trinity Church website] }} '''Holy Trinity Church, Dalston''', also known as the '''Clowns’ Church''' is a [[Church of England]] parish church in Beechwood Road in the borough of [[London Borough of Hackney|Hackney]], north [[London]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.londontown.com/LondonInformation/Attraction/Holy_Trinity,_The_Clowns_Church/0c6d/ |title=Holy Trinity, The Clowns' Church in London | Nearby hotels, shops and restaurants |publisher=LondonTown.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-19}}</ref> It is in the parish of Holy Trinity with St Philip Dalston and [[All Saints Church, Haggerston]] (St Philip having been bombed during the [[World War II|war]] and demolished some time between 1947 and 1952).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=22712 |title=Hackney - List of Churches | A History of the County of Middlesex: Volume 10 (pp. 122-128) |publisher=British-history.ac.uk |date=1977-03-15 |accessdate=2014-01-19}}</ref>
From 1998 to 2014, the vicar was [[Rose Hudson-Wilkin]], who also holds the roles of [[Speaker of the House of Commons (United Kingdom)|Speaker]]’s chaplain to the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]], priest vicar at [[Westminster Abbey]] and chaplain to the [[Elizabeth II|Queen]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.churchofengland.org/our-views/the-church-in-parliament/speaker%27s-chaplain/revd-rose-hudson-wilkin.aspx |title=Revd Rose Hudson-Wilkin |publisher=Churchofengland.org |date= |accessdate=2014-01-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2012/12/22/rev-rose-hudson-wilkin-church-sex_n_2350729.html |title=Rev Rose Hudson-Wilkin, First Black Female Chaplain To Queen Hits Out Over Women Bishops, Gay Marriage |publisher=Huffingtonpost.co.uk |date=2012-12-22 |accessdate=2014-01-19}}</ref>
==History and design== Holy Trinity was designed by [[Ewan Christian]] – a noted church builder and restorer and architect of the [[National Portrait Gallery, London|National Portrait Gallery]].<ref>{{cite web|author=David Goold |url=http://www.scottisharchitects.org.uk/architect_full.php?id=203623 |title=Dictionary of Scottish Architects - DSA Architect Biography Report (January 19, 2014, 3:13 pm) |publisher=Scottisharchitects.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-01-19}}</ref> The main phase of construction took place in 1878-79 and was funded from the proceeds of the sale of [[St Martin Outwich]] in the [[City of London]].<ref name="britishlistedbuildings1">{{cite web|author=Good Stuff IT Services |url=http://www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/en-426309-holy-trinity-greater-london-authority |title=Holy Trinity - Hackney - Greater London - England |publisher=British Listed Buildings |date= |accessdate=2014-01-19}}</ref>
It is a [[Listed building|Grade II]]-listed building; its 1975 designation noted both the reputation of its architect and its impressive [[High Victorian Gothic|High Victorian]] style with continental influences.<ref name="britishlistedbuildings1"/>
It is constructed in red brick in the [[English Gothic architecture|Early English style]] and has a slate roof. Inside Holy Trinity is a screen brought from St Philip, Dalston after that church was damaged by bombing in December 1940. The post-war east window of the church has glass by A. F. Erridge.<ref name="britishlistedbuildings1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/a2a/records.aspx?cat=074-p79phi&cid=-1#-1 |title=Access to Archives |publisher=The National Archives |date= |accessdate=2014-01-19}}</ref>
==The Clowns' Church== Holy Trinity is known as the Clowns’ Church for the annual [[Clowns International]] service held on the first Sunday in February in honour of [[Joseph Grimaldi]] and deceased clowns. The service was established in 1946/7 at St James’s Episcopal Chapel in Pentonville Road, where Grimaldi is buried (now Joseph Grimaldi Park).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.londongardensonline.org.uk/gardens-online-record.asp?ID=ISL043 |title=London Gardens Online |publisher=London Gardens Online |date= |accessdate=2014-01-19}}</ref> It moved to Holy Trinity in 1959 after St James's was deconsecrated.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|last=Dangerfield |first=Andy |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-21319024 |title=BBC News - Clowns in Joseph Grimaldi church tribute service |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2013-02-04 |accessdate=2014-01-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clowns-international.com/ |title=Home |publisher=Clowns-international.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=They’re having a laugh: Grimaldi Clown Church Service |url=http://now-here-this.timeout.com/2013/02/01/theyre-having-a-laugh-grimaldi-clown-church-service/ |title=They’re having a laugh: Grimaldi Clown Church Service – Now. Here. This. – Time Out London |publisher=Now-here-this.timeout.com |date=2013-02-01 |accessdate=2014-01-19}}</ref> The service is attended by clowns in full costume and is usually followed by a performance for members of the public.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
The vestry of Holy Trinity Church is home to the [[Clowns Gallery-Museum]], which includes the Clown Egg Register.

{{Italic title}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2016}} [[Image:Dama de Elche (M.A.N. Madrid) 01.jpg|thumb|250px|''Lady of Elche'']]
The '''''Lady of Elche''''' or '''''Lady of Elx''''' (in Spanish, '''''Dama de Elche''''') is a [[limestone]]<ref name="ABC">{{cite news|title=Misterios sin aclarar de la Dama de Elche|url=http://www.abc.es/historia/abci-misterios-sin-aclarar-dama-elche-201608041257_noticia.html|work=[[ABC (Spain)]]|date=4 August 2016}}</ref> [[Bust (sculpture)|bust]] that was discovered in 1897 at ''L'Alcúdia,'' an archaeological site on a private estate two kilometers south of [[Elche]], [[Spain]]. It is currently exhibited in the [[National Archaeological Museum of Spain]] in Madrid.
It is generally known as an [[Iberians|Iberian]] artifact from the 4th century BC, although the artisanship suggests strong Hellenistic influences.<ref>Francisco Vives Boix, ''La Dama de Elche en el año 2000 : Análisis tecnológico y artístico'' [http://dama.esy.es/Dama2000/Bienvenida.html].</ref> According to ''The Encyclopedia of Religion'', the ''Lady of Elche'' is believed to have a direct association with [[Tanit]], the goddess of Carthage, who was worshiped by the [[Carthaginian Iberia|Punic-Iberians]].<ref>''The Encyclopedia of Religion'', Macmillan Library Ref. USA - Iberian Religion - page 549</ref>
==Sculpture== {{Main|Iberian sculpture}}
The originally [[polychrome]]d bust is thought to represent a woman wearing an elaborate [[headdress]] and large wheel-like coils (known as ''rodetes'') on each side of the face. The opening in the rear of the sculpture indicates it may have been used as a [[funerary urn]]. [[Image:DamaElche01.JPG|thumb|230px|left|Detail of the Lady of Elche]]
Other artifacts associated with Iberian culture are the ''[[Lady of Guardamar]]'' −which has similar wheel-like rodetes and necklaces− or the ''[[Lady of Baza]]''. While the ''Lady of Elche'' is a bust, there are indications that it was part of a seated statue, similar to the ''Lady of Baza'' (with which it shares similar necklance pendants) or a standing one like the ''[[Gran Dama Oferente]]'' from Cerro de los Santos ([[Montealegre del Castillo]], [[Albacete (province)|Albacete]]).
These three figures and the ''[[Bicha of Balazote]]'' are exhibited in the same Iberian art hall in the [[National Archaeological Museum of Spain]] in Madrid.
==Discovery and repatriation== [[Image:Dama de Elche colores2007.jpg|150px|thumb|Color reconstruction by Francisco Vives]] The sculpture was found on 4 August 1897, by a young worker, Manuel Campello Esclapez. The popular version of the story differs from the official report by Pere Ibarra (the local keeper of the records) which stated that Antonio Maciá found the bust. Ibarra's version of the discovery story, was that farm workers clearing the southeast slope of [[archaeological site of La Alcudia|La Alcudia]] for agricultural purposes, discovered the sculpture. The bust was quickly nicknamed "''Reina Mora''" or "[[Moors|Moorish]] Queen" by locals.<ref name="ABC"/>
An archaeological site is now located where the bust of Elche was discovered. Evidence has been found there of an Iberian-Punic settlement, a Roman sewer, walls and Roman houses, and mosaics. One mosaic shows an effigy of [[Abdon and Sennen|Saint Abdon]], belonging to a Christian [[basilica]] of the 5th century. The latter archaeological evidence is supported by the [[codex|codices]] of the councils of [[Toledo, Spain|Toledo]] where it discusses an audience with bishops from ''Illici'' (Elche).
Dr. Campello, owner of the farm, was married to Asunción Ibarra, daughter of [[Aureliano Ibarra Manzoni]], a [[Humanism|humanist]] from the 19th century whose hobby was [[archeology]]. Ibarra Manzoni had found a number of objects and Iberian vestiges on his own farmland and in other places in the municipality of Elche. He built up a valuable collection, which he bequeathed to his daughter Asunción. He provided instructions that she make the necessary arrangements for the collection to be offered for sale to the [[Real Academia de la Historia]]<nowiki/> after her death, to be located finally at the National Archaeological Museum. The will specified that the collection be sold in its entirety. The family placed the Lady on their balcony so that it could be viewed by all of the residents of Elche.<ref name="ABC"/>
Don Pedro Ibarra invited French archaeologist [[Pierre Paris]] to his home to see the ''[[Mystery Play of Elche]]''. When the archaeologist saw the Iberian bust, he recognized its worth and notified the [[Louvre]] in Paris. The Louvre offered a large sum of money for the time: 4000 [[French franc|francs]], and purchased the sculpture within a few weeks of its discovery. Despite opposition from Doña Asuncion, the Iberian bust was sold. On 30 August 1897, the sculpture was sent to the Louvre.
For 40 years the ''Dama de Elche'' was exhibited at the Louvre. After the start of [[World War II]] in 1939, as a precaution, the sculpture was transferred for safe-keeping to the castle of [[Montauban]] near Toulouse.<ref name="ABC"/> The [[Vichy government]] negotiated the statue's return to Spain with [[Francoist Spain|Franco's government]]. In 1941 it was returned through an exchange of works (which also included the [[The Immaculate of Soult|''Immaculate Conception of the Venerable Ones'']] (or ''Immaculate Conception of Soult'') by [[Bartolome Esteban Murillo|Murillo]], the twin sphinxes of [[El Salobral]] and several pieces of the [[Treasure of Guarrazar]], and the Iberian sculptures of [[Osuna]]. In return Spain transferred to France a portrait of [[Mariana of Austria]] by [[Diego Velázquez|Velázquez]] (the Prado kept another existing version of the portrait, which was considered of superior quality)<ref name="ABC"/> and a ''[[Portrait of Antonio de Covarrubias]]'' by [[El Greco]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.museodelprado.es/index.php?id=763 |title=Encyclopedia of the Prado/Timeline museum/1941 |accessdate=April 28, 2009 |author=Prado}}</ref> Since 1941, the ''Lady of Elche'' has been officially owned by the [[Museo del Prado]] (catalog number E433).
The discovery of the ''Lady of Elche'' initiated a popular interest in pre-Roman Iberian culture. She appeared on a 1948 Spanish one-[[Spanish peseta|peseta]] banknote and was mentioned in [[William Gaddis]]'s ''The Recognitions'' (1955).
In 1971 it was transferred from El Prado to the [[National Archaeological Museum of Spain]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.museodelprado.es/enciclopedia/enciclopedia-on-line/voz/dama-de-elche-anonimo/|title=Enciclopedia On-Line/Dama de Elche (anonymous) |accessdate=April 29, 2009 |author=Prado Museum}}</ref> where it is currently exhibited. [[File:Lady of Elche at the National Arquaeological Museum, Madrid (Spain).jpg|thumb|432x432px|Lady of Elche at the National Arquaeological Museum, Madrid (Spain)]]
===Exhibitions in Elche===
In 1965 the ''Dama de Elche'' returned briefly to Elche, on the occasion of the seventh centenary of ''[[Mystery Play of Elche]]''.
On 19 January 2006, the Minister of Culture of Spain, [[Carmen Calvo]], issued a decision to temporarily lease the Lady to its hometown. From 18 May 2006, to 1 November 2006. the ''Dama de Elche'' presided over the inauguration of the Museum of Archaeology and History of Elche (in the [[Palacio de Altamira (Elche)|Palace of Altamira]]) and the exhibition From Ilici to Elx, 2500 Years of History that took place in different locations in the city. It was represented by an exact replica afterwards.<ref>[http://www.factum-arte.com/pag/47/-p-Facsimile-of-the-Dama-De-Elche--p- Facsimile of the Dama de Elche executed by Adam Lowe's studio Factum Arte in Madrid (2002-2005)] accessed 14 November 2014</ref><ref>[http://www.visitelche.com/turismo-cultural/visitas/elche/museos/museo-arqueologico-y-de-historia-de-elche-mahe/ Museo Arqueológico y de Historia de Elche (MAHE)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141101220306/http://www.visitelche.com/turismo-cultural/visitas/elche/museos/museo-arqueologico-y-de-historia-de-elche-mahe/ |date=1 November 2014 }}, accessed 14 November 2014</ref>
==Contention of forgery== The bust was first accused of being a forgery in 1906, in an essay called 'Las esculturas del Cerro de los Santos, cuestion de autenticidad' by archeologist [[José Ramón Mélida]]. [[File:Dama de Baza detail.jpg| ''Lady of Baza''|right|thumb|The [[Lady of Baza]], another Iberian "lady" bust.]] In 1995, [[John F. Moffitt]], an art historian specializing in painting,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.klowry.com/2008/06/jack-moffitt-1940-2008.html|title=Jack Moffitt, 1940-2008|work=klowry.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090304135140/http://www.klowry.com/2008/06/jack-moffitt-1940-2008.html|archivedate=4 March 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref> published ''Art Forgery: The Case of the Lady of Elche'', [[University Press of Florida]], in which he contended that the statue was a [[archaeological forgery|forgery]] with similarities to [[Symbolism (arts)|symbolist art]] of the [[Belle Époque]]. He speculated that the identity of the forger and commissioner was "a physician and resident surgeon in the town of Elche" who was "well informed about the current state of Iberian studies" and owned "the fertile archaeological site of La Alcúdia."
Experts in Spanish archaeology have rejected Moffitt's theory and accept the ''Lady of Elche'' as a genuine ancient Iberian work. Antonio Uriarte of the University of Madrid has stated: "Decade by decade, research has reinforced the coherence of the Lady within the corpus of Iberian sculpture. The Lady was found more than a century ago, and many of its features, not then understood, have been confirmed by subsequent finds. For example, the use of paint in Iberian sculpture was unknown when the Lady appeared."<ref>R. Olmos and T. Tortosa, in Gocha R. Tsetskhladze (ed.), ''Ancient Greeks West and East'', Leiden: Brill, 1999, brief summary here [http://ccat.sas.upenn.edu/bmcr/2000/2000-03-20.html]</ref> A [[Consejo Superior de Investigaciones Científicas]] (CSIC) study on the Lady of Elche's micropigmentation published in 2005 concluded that the trace pigments on the statue were consistent with ancient materials and that no modern pigments had been found.<ref>M. P. Luxán, J. L. Prada, F. Dorrego, 2005, "Dama de Elche: pigments, surface coating and stone of the sculpture", ''Materials and structures'', 38(277), pp. 419-424. [https://www.rilem.net/boutique/fiche.php?cat=journal&reference=1645]{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} See also [http://www.springerlink.com/content/g3867m6578u5v27p/]</ref>
In 2011, María Pilar Luxán,<ref>Luxán, Mª P. ''et al'' (2011). Human bone ashes found in the ''Dama de Elche'' (5th-4th century B.C.) reveal its use as an ancient cinerary urn. ''Journal of Cultural Heritage vol. 12, issue 3, pp. 310-316.''</ref> the author of the 2005 study, analyzed microparticles within the back hole of the ''Dama d'Elx'' utilizing [[Electron Microscope|electron microscopy]] and [[X-ray spectroscopy|X-ray dispersive spectrometry]]. Luxán deduced that the particles belonged to the ashes of human bones and that they compared with those of the Iberian period. She concluded that the statue was used as a [[funeral urn|funerary urn]] in the Iberian period, thus guaranteeing its antiquity and confirming the hypothesis about its function.
==In modern culture== French artist [[James Tissot]] based figures in several of his turn-of-the-century paintings on the recently discovered ''Lady of Elche''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://members.bib-arch.org/image.asp?PubID=BSBR&Volume=07&Issue=04&ImageID=02900&SourcePage=publication.asp&UserID=0&|title=Picture - The BAS Library|work=bib-arch.org}}</ref> [[File:Jephthah’s Daughter by James Tissot.jpg|150px|thumb|''Jephthah's Daughter'' by James Tissot, based on the Lady of Elche.]]
The Dama de Elche makes an appearance in Part III of [[William Gaddis]]'s 1955 novel ''[[The Recognitions]]'', when the character Wyatt Gwyon examines a one peseta note and calls the engraving of the bust a "beautiful thing".<ref>{{cite book |last= Gaddis|first= William|date= 1985|orig-year= 1955|title= The Recognitions|url= |location= |publisher= Penguin Books|page= 782|isbn=978-0-14-007768-1 |author-link= }}</ref>

The [[Soviet Union]] actively tried to incorporate [[Marxism|Marxist]] ideals into the study of [[linguistics]].
Linguists had important positions in the early Soviet state, as they were needed to develop alphabets for languages that previously had never been written.<ref name=BrandistChown>{{cite book |title=Politics and the Theory of Language in the USSR 1917–1938 |editor1=Craig Brandist |editor2=Katya Chown |url=http://universitypublishingonline.org/anthem/ebook.jsf?bid=CBO9780857289483 |accessdate=11 January 2015}}</ref>
In the 1920s, language began to be seen as a social phenomenon, and Russian and Soviet linguists tried to give a sociological explanation to features of language. At the same time, Soviet linguists sought to develop a "Marxist" linguistics, as opposed to the early theories that were viewed as [[bourgeois]]. Based on this, linguists focused more on the spoken forms of the language, and devoted more time to the study of non-standard dialects than previous linguists had done. This can be seen in the work of [[Boris Alexandrovich Larin]] and [[Lev Petrovich Iakubinskii]].<ref name=BrandistChown/>
The leading linguist of the early Soviet era was [[Nicholas Marr]], known for his [[Japhetic theory]]. The theory suggested that the [[Kartvelian languages]] had a common origin with the [[Semitic languages]]. He also applied the idea of [[class struggle]] to the development of language. After Marr died, a likely ghost-written article credited to [[Stalin]] blasted Marr's theory, stating "Soviet linguistics cannot be advanced on the basis of an incorrect formula which is contrary to the whole course of the history of peoples and languages." Politically, World War II caused a rise in [[nationalism]], which Japhetic theory argued against. This theory was never accepted outside the Soviet Union.<ref>THOMAS JOHN SAMUELIAN, "THE SEARCH FOR A MARXIST LINGUISTICS IN THE SOVIET UNION, 1917-1950" (January 1, 1981). Dissertations available from ProQuest. Paper AAI8117848.</ref>

'''Lurish music''' is referred to an ethno-cultural characteristic of [[Lurs|Lurs]] in the [[middle-east]]. The Lurish music enjoys a various and ancient background,<ref>Majedi, H and S. Shamlukia, (2008): Investigating the impact of nature and the environmen on the Iranian music.(In Persian) Environmental sciences and technology: volume13, Number2, Pages 95-103</ref><ref>Saeb, Reza. [http://bamdadelorestan.ir/?p=170] "Music status in Luristan"], ''[[Bamdadelorestan]]'', KhorramAbad, 19 October 2015. Retrieved on 03 July 2017.</ref> and it can be divided into two parts; vocal music and [[instrumental]]. [[File:Lurish-Sorna.jpg|320px|thumb|right|A Lur musician performing [[Sorna]] at a wedding ceremony]]
== Types of Music == Based on the songs, the Lurish music is divided into seven sections; * Music of lyrics and romantic songs: Including music regarding lyrics that is about the expression of both the pain of loss or separation and the beauty of love in spite of that pain. These musics like Heylaw, Binâ-binâ, [[Khosrow and Shirin|Shirin & Khosrow]] lyrics, Sârixâni and Miruna (Mirbaygi) are performed in different Lurish music [[mugham]]s. * Music of Epic-Combat songs: These hymns represent the epic and combat values of the warriors among the tribes. The most famous examples of this section are Jange Loru and Dâya-Dâya. * Music and songs of mourning: This music has more to do with the rituals and has been used extensively in mourning ceremonies from the ancient times. Čamari (also Čamariuna), Sahari, Šivani and Pâkotali are from the most famous of these moghams. * Music and songs of seasons: music and special songs of different seasons like Barza-kuhi, Kuč-bâru and Mâla-jiri * Music and songs related to work activities: To ease and speed up the work of nomadic men and women, these songs (e.g Barziari, Hawla)are sung individually or collectively. * Comic music and songs: These are usually originated from impromptu satires about people, places or objects and are sometimes accompanied by humorous dramatic movements of someone or people. * Religious hymn-music: These are generally based on the words of [[Yarsanism|Yaresan]] (from the hymns of Ahle-haq), and their mystical and religious aspects are very deep.
== Music instruments == The most popular Lurish musical instruments include [[Sorna]], [[Dohol]], Tâl (Lurish [[kamancheh]]),<ref>Oloumo, M.(2015).Kamanche, the Bowed String Instrument of the Orient.International Journal of Arts and Commerce.Vol4, No 1, 92-101, available online at:[http://www.ijac.org.uk/January2015]</ref> [[Tonbak]] (Tomak), and the common Iranian traditional instruments. Meanwhile, the Lurish kamancheh is the only one that is fundamentally different from other ethnic music instruments.<ref>[http://issuu.com/talllorestan/docs/_________________ تحقیق در مورد تال (کمانچه لرستان)]، سید رسول صدریه.</ref> The Lurs select the [[Dastgāh-e Māhur|Mâhur]] as their basic musical step to showcase the magnificence, grandeur and independence of their people.<ref>Majedi, H and S. Shamlukia, (2008): Investigating the impact of nature and the environment on the Iranian music.(In Persian) Environmental sciences and technology: volume13, Number2, Pages 95-103</ref>
=== After 1979 revolution of Iran === After [[Iranian Revolution|1979 revolution of Iran]] due to intense encounters with musical performances, especially ethnic music, the amount of music participation in different parts of the life of the [[Lurs]] was reduced however in the past, cheerful music and lyrics were accompanied with collective dance.

[[File:Native_American_Manos_Arizona_2014.jpg|300px|thumb|[[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]] manos from [[Arizona]].]]
A '''mano''' ([[Spanish language|Spanish]] for ''hand'') is a [[ground stone]] tool used with a [[metate]] to process or grind food by hand.<ref>[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/mano ''Mano.''] Merriam-Webster Dictionary. Retrieved December 9, 2011.</ref>
== History == Manos were used in [[prehistory|prehistoric]] times to process wild seeds, nuts and other food, generally used with greater frequency in the [[Archaic period in the Americas|Archaic period]], when people became more reliant upon local wild plant food for their diet. Later, manos and metates were used to process cultivated [[maize]].<ref name=Gibbon>Gibbon, Guy E.; Ames, Kenneth M. (1998) [https://books.google.com/books?id=_0u2y_SVnmoC&pg=PA24 ''Archaeology of Prehistoric Native America: An Encyclopedia''.] pp. 107, 166. {{ISBN|0-8153-0725-X}}.</ref>
In its early use in the [[Southwestern United States|American Southwest]], the mano and metate were used to grind wild plants. The mano began as a one-handed tool and once cultivation of maize became more prevalent, the mano became a larger, two-handed tool that more efficiently ground food against an evolved basin or trough metate.<ref>[[Stephen Plog|Plog, Stephen]]. (1997). ''Ancient Peoples of the American Southwest.'' London: Thames and Hudson. pp. 68-70. {{ISBN|0-500-02116-3}}.</ref>
Besides food, manos and metates were used to separate and pulverize [[clay]] from earthen debris and stones. The resulting clay was used for [[pottery]]-making.<ref>[[Stephen Plog|Plog, Stephen]]. (1997). ''Ancient Peoples of the American Southwest.'' London: Thames and Hudson. p. 66. {{ISBN|0-500-02116-3}}.</ref>
== Grinding process == [[File:Metate-and-Mano.jpg|thumb|Metate and mano.]]
A mano, a smooth hand-held stone, is used against a [[metate]], typically a large stone with a depression or bowl. The movement of the mano against the metate consists of a circular, rocking or chopping grinding motion using one or both hands.<ref>Sutteon, Mark Q.; Arkush, Brooke S. (2001). ''Archaeological Laboratory Methods: An Introduction.''] Kendall/Hunt Publishing Company. p. 72-75. {{ISBN|0-7872-8153-0}}.</ref>
[[Ancient Pueblo People]] often set up work rooms, called mealing rooms, that were established with sets of manos and metates for mass grinding efforts.<ref>[[Stephen Plog|Plog, Stephen]]. (1997). ''Ancient Peoples of the American Southwest.'' London: Thames and Hudson. p. 80. {{ISBN|0-500-02116-3}}.</ref>
==See also== * [[Bedrock mortar#Bedrock metate|Bedrock metate]] * [[Grinding slab]] * [[Quern-stone]]
